attributes.title: Choice repetition bias in intertemporal choice

q1.value: Repetition bias in intertemporal choice: An eye-tracking study

q2.value: Ulrike Senftleben, Martin Schoemann, Stefan Scherbaum

q3.value:
In a series of choices, people have a tendency to repeat their decision (i.e., choice repetition or choice history bias). This effect is largely neglected in studies of value-based decision making. Here, we use eye-tracking to investigate how this choice perseveration effect emerges in intertemporal choices. We expect to see choice perseveration effects as indicated by a higher amount of choice repetitions than choice switches, and shorter response times for choice repetitions than for choice switches. 
Further, using eye-tracking allows us to uncover attentional processes in intertemporal decisions. For example, do people pay more attention to one choice dimension than to the other (e.g., more fixations on time than on reward)? Does attentional processing directly predict the eventual choice? Does the repetition bias affect attentional processing?
In order to answer these questions, we have developed an intertemporal choice paradigm that consists of two parts. Throughout the experiment, participants choose between a small/soon (SS) option that is available sooner, but has a smaller value, and a large/late (LL) option that is available later, but has a larger value (e.g., 10 € right now or 19 € in 14 days). In the first part, the measurement block, the SS and LL options are constructed to cover a wide range of reward values and time intervals in order to measure participants' individual delay discounting. We then use this individual delay discounting to tailor trials to each individual participant in the second part, the experimental block. In the experimental block, we construct mini-blocks of three trials: Two bias trials and one target trial. The two bias trials are attractive SS or attractive LL trials (i.e., participants are highly likely to choose the SS in attractive SS trials/LL in attractive LL trials), and the target trial is neutral (both options are equally attractive and equally likely to be chosen). This allows us to measure if, in the neutral target trial, people choose differently depending on their bias-sequence (i.e., will people choose the LL option more often in the neutral target trial after choosing LL in an LL-biased sequence, vs.  after choosing SS in an SS-biased sequence? How does that affect response time? How does that affect attentional processing?).
Our hypotheses are based on our own findings in pilot studies and previous work (e.g., Scherbaum et al., 2016; Senftleben et al., 2019; Senftleben, Schoemann, Rudolf, & Scherbaum, 2019), and on an eye-tracking study on intertemporal decision making (Franco-Watkins, Mattson, & Jackson, 2016).

q4.value:
** behavioral**
1.) Participants will show a tendency to repeat their decisions, as indicated by a higher percentage of LL target choices after an LL-biased sequence than after an SS-biased sequence.  
2.) Response times will be higher when target choices are a switch from the bias choice (i.e., LL target choice after SS-biased sequence and SS target choice after LL-biased sequence) than when target choices are a repetition of the bias choice (i.e., SS target choice after SS-biased sequence and LL target choice after LL-biased sequence).
3.) Response times in LL choices will be higher than response times in SS choices.
** eye-tracking**
4.) We expect participants to pay more attention to the monetary dimension than the time dimension, as indicated by a higher amount of fixations on monetary Areas of Interests (AOIs) than on time AOIs. 
5.) We expect attentional preferences for the SS or LL option to predict choice, as indicated by fixation frequencies for SS and LL AOIs. 
6.) We expect the last fixated AOI to predict choice.
7.) The repetition bias affects attentional processing: The choice in the bias trial affects attentional preferences in the subsequent target trial (i.e., choice of  SS in bias trial leads to more fixation on SS AOIs than LL AOIs in the subsequent target trial). 
8.) We assume that, in target trials, people show an attentional bias towards the temporal feature dimension after SS bias choices and towards the value dimension after LL bias choices.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Within-subject design. Measurement block and Experimental block stimuli are randomized within the respective block.

q9.value:
All randomizations are within-subject, with the exception of the position of the monetary and temporal units (days and Euros). The value information (monetary value in Euros) appears either at the top of the screen with the temporal information (delay in days) at the bottom; or vice versa. This is constant within-subjects and balanced across subjects. 
Randomization of monetary values and delays is applied separately for the Measurement block and for the Experimental block (because the stimuli for the Experimental block depend on the subjects' choices in the Measurement block and are thus only generated after the Measurement block is completed).
For the Measurement block, the LL option can take the following reward values: 19.00, 19.50, 20.00, 20.50, 21.00 €, and SS reward is either 20, 50, 75, 85, 90, 93, 95 or 97% of the LL value (rounded to the closest .00 or .50 €). The SS option is available in 0 or 7 days, while the LL option is available in additional 3, 5, 10, 20, 35, or 60 days. All possible option values are repeatedly orthogonally combined to generate a trial set where each combination is repeated three times. The order of this trial set is then randomized. 
For the experimental part, the reward values and time intervals depend on subjects' individual delay discounting. The randomization procedure is implemented as described above for the Measurement block: all possible combinations of SS/LL reward values/time intervals will be combined to create mini-blocks of two biased trials (either SS or LL) and one target trial; the order of these mini-blocks is then randomized.
We also randomize the position of the SS option and the LL option. For the measurement block, the position of the SS option is randomly set to left or right on a trial-to-trial basis (with the LL option being on the opposite side of the screen). For the experimental block, randomization differs depending on the trial type. In the first trial in a mini-block, the position of the SS option is randomly set to left or right. In the second and third trial in a mini-block (bias and target trial), the following four scenarios are balanced according to if they were a repetition or a switch from the position of the previous trial: 1) bias repetition & target repetition, 2) bias switch & target repetition, 3) bias repetition & target switch, 4) bias switch & target switch. These four scenarios are presented in randomized order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit human subjects from the ORSEE-based database of the Department of Psychology of the TU Dresden, Dresden, Germany. Subjects will give informed consent and they will receive reimbursement of 8 € per hour. Additionally, one of their decisions will be realized (i.e., if they choose to receive 5€ right now, they will receive 5 € at the end of the experiment; if they choose to receive 10 € in 14 days, they will receive 10 € in 14 days).
Data collection will begin in December 2019 and will carry on until 50 complete data sets are collected (approx. May 2020). 
Subjects are included in the study if they fulfil the following criteria:
- normal vision (or corrected-to-normal by wearing glasses)
- age between 18 and 40 years 
- no history of neurological disorders

q13.value: We will collect 50 complete data sets (for remarks on what "complete" means, see the point Stopping rule).

q14.value: Based on a pilot study (n=21), we obtained an effect size estimate for the response time switch cost effect of g=.37. To detect such a one-tailed effect of g=.37 at an alpha-level of .05 and a power of .80, we need a sample size of 47 participants (as calculated using GPower (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007)). To account for the possibility of post-hoc exclusion of subjects due to low eye-tracking data quality or technical issues, we aim for a sample size of 50 subjects.

q15.value:
While we do have control over the final sample size and will stop data collection only when 50 complete data sets are collected, our experiment has two points where participants may be excluded:
1. If subjects have an extremely high or extremely low discounting rate in the first block, our paradigm's experimental manipulation in the second block may not work (i.e., it may not be possible to create trials where the SS option is 30% above/30% below the indifference point). If this is the case, the experiment will automatically abort and the participant will not move on to the experimental part. This is programmed into the experiment and happens without any input from the experimenter or the subject. Thus, data collection for that subject is incomplete; this subject will be excluded from all analysis and will not count towards the planned sample size of 50. 
2. If there are, for any reason, issues pertaining to the eye-tracking that become apparent during the experiment, the experimenter can decide to stop the session and exclude this participant.  This participant will then again not be included for data analysis and will not count towards the final sample size.

question.value:
We will manipulate the following variables:
- monetary rewards of the SS and of the LL option
- time interval of the SS and of the LL option
- placement on the computer screen (is the SS option on the right or left side of the screen; is the monetary value at the top or the bottom of the screen)

We will measure the following variables for confirmatory analysis:
- choices (SS or LL)
- response times (time from trial start until button press indicating the choice)
- eye movement of right pupil (raw data as recorded using an Eyelink 1000 desk-mounted eye-tracker (SR Research, Ontario, Canada), using the combined pupil and corneal reflection setting). Saccades and fixation events are automatically defined online by the host system. The Eyelink software applies a velocity-based algorithm combined with acceleration criteria to detect saccade onsets and offsets. Based on the fixations and saccades defined by the Eyelink software, a variety of eye-tracking measures can be calculated (fixation frequency, fixation duration, fixation order etc., for more details see point Indices below))

- indifference point: Indifference points describe the value difference at which participants choose indifferently between the two options, that is, the probability of choosing the late-large (LL) option over the soon-small (SS) option, given a specific interval, is 50%. As an estimate of the indifference point, the point of inflection of a logistic function will be fitted to each participant’s choice data (SS option vs. LL option) as a function of increasing value differences (Scherbaum et al., 2013). If the estimation of the indifference points is invalid (i.e. the estimated indifference points lie outside the range of 0 to 1), they will be corrected. Based on the indifference points for the distances used in the measurement block, we will interpolate the indifference points for the remaining distances. We will use either a linear, hyperbolic, or exponential model for interpolation based on the best fit with the available indifference points. As a result, we will have estimates of indifference points for each distance, which we will then use to construct trials in the subsequent experimental part. Furthermore, we will fit a hyperbolic discounting model g(D)= 1/(1 + kD), where g(D) is the discount factor, D is the time interval or delay, and k is the individual discounting parameter. This will return k-values for all individuals as a measure of delay discounting. 
As k-parameters are usually not normally distributed, we will apply log-transformation in order to better meet assumptions of parametric tests.
- as indicator for choice behavior, we will calculate (for each condition) the mean percentage of LL choices. For hypotheses regarding choice repetition, we will focus on choice percentages in target trials after successful bias trials (i.e., where participants chose SS in SS bias trials and LL in LL bias trials).
- Response times will be averaged for each condition and log-transformed before statistical analysis (as they are likely not normally distributed). 
- Eye-tracking: After removing blinks, we will compute for each trial the number of fixations in total, number of fixations on each Area of Interest (AOI) (SS value, SS interval, LL value, LL interval), AOI acquisitions and reacquisitions, fixation duration of each fixation, mean fixation duration in total, mean fixation duration on each AOI, order of fixations (i.e., which AOI was fixated first, second,...last).
- AOIs are defined as a visual angle margin of 1° the borders of the stimulus boxes (see Orquin, Ashby, & Clarke, 2016, JBDM)  
- as indicator for selective attention, we will compute a selection bias score (Franco-Watkins et al., 2016): [(n fixations SS time + n fixations SS money) -  (n fixations LL time + n fixations LL money)]/total fixations, where 1=extreme bias to SS,-1=extreme bias to LL, 0=no bias

Hypothesis 1: one-tailed paired t-test of percentage of LL choices in SS-biased target trials vs. in LL-biased target trials
Hypothesis 2: one-tailed paired t-test of response times of target choices that repeat the bias choice (i.e., LL choice after LL-biased trial and SS choice after SS-biased trial) vs. target choices that switch from the bias choice (i.e., LL choice after SS-biased trial and SS choice after LL-biased trial)
Hypothesis 3: one-tailed paired t-test of response times in SS target choices and response times in LL target choices
Hypothesis 4: one-tailed paired t-test on average amount of fixations on monetary AOIs vs. time AOIs
Hypothesis 5: logistic regression with selection bias as predictor and choice (SS/LL) as outcome 
Hypothesis 6: logistic regression with last AOI (SS/LL) as predictor and choice (SS/LL) as outcome
Hypothesis 7: one-tailed paired t-test between selection bias after SS bias choice and selection bias after LL bias choice [higher SB score after SS bias choice than after LL bias choice]
Hypothesis 8: one-tailed paired t-tests between number of fixations on time dimension and on value dimension, conducted separately for targets after SS bias choice and targets after LL bias choice

q20.value: K-values and response times will be log-transformed for statistical analysis.

q22.value:
All data of incomplete data sets will be excluded (see sample size and stopping rule for how incomplete data sets are defined). 
The experiment contains 16 catch trials (where one option is available earlier in time and has a higher monetary value; not choosing this option is considered an error). If participants make an error in more than 2 of these catch trials, they will be excluded from data analysis.
We will further exclude participants if the quality of the eye-tracking data is unacceptably low, or if participants only ever looked at AOIs associated with one choice option (as this would indicate no serious engagement with the task).

q23.value: If data are incomplete or missing and these data are necessary for confirmatory data analysis (i.e., data are missing from the experimental block of the experiment), we will exclude all data of that participant from data analysis. If our economic resources allow for it, we will recruit a new participant as a replacement.

q24.value: Our confirmatory hypothesis all focus on fixation frequency. We will also look at other eye-tracking measures (i.e., dwell time, mean fixation duration, number of reacquisitions) to see if they reveal the same qualitative results or if some measures are more sensitive than others.

q25.value: Please note that, due to time pressure, data collection had already begun at the date of submission. Data of four participants had been collected but were neither accessed nor analyzed. Therefore, we selected "registration prior to data collection" to best describe this situation.

attributes.title: Can heat exposure interrupt memory reconsolidation? A pre-registered report
attributes.description: Study of heat exposure in sauna on memory processes

q1.value: Can heat exposure interfere with memory reconsolidation? A pre-registered report

q2.value: Jesus Armando Cudeiro González, Emilio Gutiérrez, David Soto

q3.value: Propranolol, a beta-adrenergic receptor antagonist commonly administered either for the treatment of hypertension, or prescribed as anxiolytic (Steenen et al., 2016), has been widely used in the study of post-reactivation amnesia in the last two decades. It has been demonstrated  propranolol affects memory reconsolidation of negative events if propranolol is administered before memory reactivation. This provided an opportunity to change emotional or traumatic memories in mental disorders such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) or Drug Addiction. Recently, we developed a pilot study to test whether heat exposure -via infrared sauna- during memory reactivation was effective at disrupting reconsolidation of emotional images (Cudeiro, Gutiérrez and Soto, 2019), based on the functional overlap of sauna and propranolol (both are used for treatment of hypertension and anxious symptomatology). We hypothesized that a unique sauna session, during memory reactivation, could block reconsolidation of emotional images learned previously, leaving the reconsolidation of neutral images intact. Surprisingly, we found that sauna produced reconsolidation impairments in both neutral and negative stimuli regardless of memory reactivation.

q4.value: If heat exposure impairs memory retrieval regardless reactivation, participants in the sauna at 50ºC condition will remember significantly fewer negative and neutral images than the sauna at 28ºC condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

question.value:
Randomised controlled trial. Participants will be allocated to two groups (sauna 50ºC/Sauna 28ºC).

Participants will be tested on 3 consecutive days: Study Phase, Sauna Phase and Recognition Phase.

Study Phase: here participants will be exposed to 50 neutral and 50 negative pictures, taken from International Affective Picture System (IAPS), presented in randomized order and will be asked to memorize these pictures. Each picture will be presented for 3 sec. Before each picture a white fixation point (diameter = 0.2º) will be presented for 1 sec. To control for possible group differences in encoding, an immediate free recall test will be given after picture presentation. In this free recall test, participants will describe verbally all pictures they could remember. Before Study Phase participants will complete the STAI (Spielberg, Gorsuch and Lushene, 1970) to prevent memory biases of participants due to anxiety states. Participants with a high score (37 or more) will be excluded.

Sauna Phase: 24h later, depending on the experimental condition, participants will receive a 7 minutes sauna session (sauna bath starting at 50º C and progressively increasing up to 60º C), or a 7 minutes sauna session at 28ºC (temperature within the limits of  thermoneutral zone in humans). Finally, all participants will be invited to take a shower.

Recognition Phase: 24h later, in the same room where the Study Phase will take place. Participants will be presented with the 100 pictures they would had seen on Day 1 and 100 new pictures (50 neutral, 50 negative) in randomized order across the different trials. Participants will be told that they should press different keys on the computer keyboard to indicate whether they recognize the picture as familiar from the study phase. Furthermore, they also will have to indicate how confident they are about their decisions using a four rating scale (1 not confident at all, and 4 completely confident). As in the Study Phase, each image will be presented during three seconds after the fixation point. Subsequently, a decision screen will be presented until the participant choose and after that, the last rating scale screen will be presented.

The two picture sets used during learning and as new pictures in the recognition test were counterbalanced across participants.

registration_responses.q1: Can heat exposure interfere with memory reconsolidation? A pre-registered report
registration_responses.q2: Jesus Armando Cudeiro González, Emilio Gutiérrez, David Soto
registration_responses.q3: Propranolol, a beta-adrenergic receptor antagonist commonly administered either for the treatment of hypertension, or prescribed as anxiolytic (Steenen et al., 2016), has been widely used in the study of post-reactivation amnesia in the last two decades. It has been demonstrated  propranolol affects memory reconsolidation of negative events if propranolol is administered before memory reactivation. This provided an opportunity to change emotional or traumatic memories in mental disorders such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) or Drug Addiction. Recently, we developed a pilot study to test whether heat exposure -via infrared sauna- during memory reactivation was effective at disrupting reconsolidation of emotional images (Cudeiro, Gutiérrez and Soto, 2019), based on the functional overlap of sauna and propranolol (both are used for treatment of hypertension and anxious symptomatology). We hypothesized that a unique sauna session, during memory reactivation, could block reconsolidation of emotional images learned previously, leaving the reconsolidation of neutral images intact. Surprisingly, we found that sauna produced reconsolidation impairments in both neutral and negative stimuli regardless of memory reactivation.

attributes.title: The effect of parental interactions on infantile aesthetic quality

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: The effect of parental interactions on infantile aesthetic quality.

other.value: Exploratory work (Eloise, 2018) was conducted to establish the veracity of such parental interactions on infantile cuteness. In order to address issues relating to replication & reproducible research, this study is conducted with pre-registered effects and methods.

analyses.value: Infantile cuteness will be compared immediately (at birth) and after a 2-week delay, to allow for sufficient dejellification. Cuteness ratings will be analyzed separately for parent and individual raters.

outliers.value:
On the basis of prior work (Eloise, 2018), it is predicted a priori that there will be a ceiling effect of infantile cuteness  (9.9/10 +- 2). 

We further predict a significant effect of infantile body mass (BMI), and thus total infant cuteness ratings will be divided by BMI to control for such a confound.

dependent.value:
Our dependent variables will be infant weight (lb) and length (in), as measured at birth by independent (and double-blinded) medical professionals.

In addition, infantile cuteness will be rated on a scale of 1-10. Raters will include both biological parents, as well as three independent observers, recruited from a developmental psychology lab at the University of Toronto.

conditions.value:
Because of the quasi-experimental nature of this design, both parents (M & F) will be self-selected on the basis of biological sex & marital relations. 

In order to generate a viable zygote [REDACTED]

hypothesis.value: Our primary goal is to replicate a previous effect showing a male x female parental interaction on infantile aesthetic quality: Specifically, previous work (Eloise, 2018) suggests that a JD * TD interaction contributes to infantile cuteness significantly greater than chance. However; to our knowledge, no attempts have been made to verify this finding through replication.

attributes.title: Behavioral and neural mechanisms of trust and cooperation in adolescence

q1.value: Behavioral and neural mechanisms of trust and cooperation in adolescence

q2.value: Gabriela Rosenblau, Christoph Korn, Ili Ma, Wenda Liu, Nikita Shah

q3.value:
Cooperation plays a central role in building interpersonal relationships, particularly in economic interactions. Trust, a necessary ingredient for both initiating and sustaining cooperation, builds on individual's readiness to explore joint rewards at the risk of facing exploitation by the other party (Adolphs, 2003; Fehr and Fischbacher, 2003). Cooperation is hard to study in systematic, controlled settings due to the fragile nature of trust and its dependence on social context. An example of how it can be studied in a controlled setting is using economic games such as the trust game (Fehr et al., 1993). The trust game is a monetary exchange game in which an investor can send a sum of money to a trustee. The trustee receives a multiple of this sum and can return any amount back to the investor (Berg et al., 1995). Using this game, researchers have demonstrated that humans have an inherent preference to trust and cooperate with people (i.e. in social settings) (Mayer et al., 2014). Studies have found that people are more willing to choose risky options and engage in cooperation with people who have lower reciprocation rates than with non-human slot machines (Fetchenhauer and Dunning, 2012). It remains unclear, however, how the opportunity to gather information about the agent shapes cooperation and how trust is achieved and sustained in social vs. non-social situations. It is also unclear how cooperation changes in adolescence, a time of substantial neural and social development.
Computational models paired with neuroscientific assessment can reveal the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying cooperation in adolescence. We will combine a developmental and neurocomputational approach to test 1) how early adolescents (8-12y, N=50) sample information about their cooperation partners, 2) which strategies they employ when cooperating with social and non-social agents, and 3) whether synchronization of neural activity between agents in the medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC) measured with near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) predicts reciprocal, sustained cooperation.

q4.value:
We will use the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) to identify optimal information sampling and cooperation strategies of adolescents in social and non-social settings. We will test whether model predictions scale with brain activity and how interpersonal neural synchronization predicts cooperation strategies. The work will proceed as follows:
AIM 1: To identify how adolescents decide to trust a peer and determine cooperation strategies of adolescents in social and non-social settings. We will determine how adolescents sample information about the other peer and how they cooperate with a peer in a repeated economic exchange game (i.e., the trust game). Based on our pilot data (see section 14 below), we expect model-free and model-based differences between social and non-social conditions (social condition: 1. when children play with their peer and 2. when they think they play with their peer but play with a computer algorithm; non-social condition: when children know that they play with the computer algorithm). A forgiveness rate will be estimated as part of model fitting. This variable will determine how fast children choose to share and "forgive" their partner after the partner defected (see section 18). H1.1. In line with a previous study (Ma et al., 2018), we expect that an uncertainty tolerance model that estimates the uncertainty tolerance criterion for each child (see section 18) best describes how children sample information about peers. H1.2. Children will show higher cooperation rates in the social compared to the non-social condition. H1.3. Children will show higher forgiveness rates, estimated by the winning mathematical model, in the social compared to the non-social conditions. 
AIM 2: To identify the neural mechanisms of cooperation. Using fNIRS, we will measure participants' brain activity during the experiment. We will focus on the MPFC, a brain region that has been uniquely involved in social decision making and learning (Behrens et al., 2008; Nicolle et al., 2012). H.2.1. Activity in the MPFC will scale with children's sharing tendencies in the social compared to non-social settings. H.2.2 Predictions of the winning mathematical models scale with neural activity in the MPFC social versus non-social conditions. 
AIM 3: To identify the interpersonal neural synchronization of the MPFC during real interactions. We will investigate the synchronization between investor and trustee pairs by computing the wavelet transform coherence (WTC; Faugeras et al., 2004) for each pair of the participants over time. H.3.1 Synchronization levels of partners will predict cooperation levels and forgiveness rates during the real interaction.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study consists of an online experiment to test information sampling, and an in-person experiment, in which children will play the trust game in pairs. We will record brain activity during the trust game task using fNIRS.
Participants (N=50, aged 8 to 12y) will first participate in an online study, in which adolescents can sample how trustworthy 60 peers were on similar games. Unbeknown to them, the outcomes of the games are computer generated and designed to have six different reciprocation rates (probability (p) of reciprocation: 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0). Adolescents are then invited into the lab in pairs and will be asked to play a child-friendly version of the trust game with each other and with computer algorithms. Pairs will be matched for age, sex, socioeconomic status and IQ. In each game, participants play multiple trials of the trust game. In this game the investor receives five coins, and can keep the five coins or share any amount with the trustee. If investors choose to share, the trustee will receive four times as many coins and can decide to share half back with the investor or keep all coins. 
	Participants play multiple consecutive games: First, participants play the trust game with each other (i.e. real interaction). One participant is randomly assigned to the trustee condition and the other to the investor condition. Thereafter, they play in the investor role with a computer partner. Before two of the four games, they are told that they are playing with a human (i.e., social condition). In the remaining games participants know that they are playing with computer partners (i.e. non-social condition). The social and non-social conditions are counterbalanced across participants.
While playing the trust game, we will measure participants' brain activity during the tasks using fNIRS. FNIRS is child friendly and tolerant of motion artifacts. It also offers considerable benefits over fMRI since it allows research on online dyadic interaction.

q9.value: Random duration of jitters between each trial are created in MATLAB. The real interaction condition is always the first condition, as to not contaminate it. The order of the remaining games in the social and non-social conditions are counterbalanced across pairs of participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We have collected behavioral data on the trust game conditions only from a pilot sample of 25 typically developing children (age = 12±2.9y). This was done to optimize parameters for the adaptive computer partners in the trust game. Aside from this behavioral pilot data (trust game task only), no data, has been collected, created, or realized as of the date of submission of this research plan for preregistration. The data collected thus far on a small sample of older participants served as pilot data to optimize experimental procedures.

question.value: Participants are recruited through advertisement by flyers around GW and online advertisement (e.g., Facebook and Instagram advertisement). Participants will complete an online study at home (approximately one hour) and an in-person study. The in-person study will take approximately two hours to complete. We expect to test all participants within a year of the start of data collection. The experiment will be completely conducted at George Washington University and we will only include participants between 8-12 years old. After completing the online study, participants will be matched for age, sex and socioeconomic variables and invited to the in-person visit in pairs. During this visit, children sit next to each other in front of a computer. Desks are separated by dividers. Each child will wear an fNIRS cap, to collect brain activity simultaneously during all experimental conditions.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 50 participants.

q14.value: The sample size is based on the number of participants included in previous similar studies, (e.g. (King-Casas et al., 2005; Tang et al., 2015) and on our pilot data. Note that model free and model-based analyses of our pilot data (N=25), revealed differences in reciprocity between social and non-social conditions. In accordance to our hypotheses, children shared more when they thought they were playing with a child (i.e., social condition) compared to when they knew they were interacting with a computer (i.e., non-social condition). Model-based analyses, revealed that a simple tit-for-tat strategy best described participants' sharing tendencies in both social and non-social conditions but the forgiveness rate significantly differed between conditions: investors reinitiated cooperation quicker after the trustee defected in the social condition. These results form the basis for our hypotheses under aims 1 and 2, stated above. To achieve a sample size of 25 participants in the real interaction condition, that is of particular interest for the fNIRS analysis, we have to collect data from 25 participant pairs (i.e., 50 participants).

question.value: Every participant gets the exact same tasks (in different order).

We will record participants' choices on the online information sampling task and in the trust game conditions. In the trust game conditions, we will also simultaneously record changes in oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin concentrations via fNIRS.

We will use linear mixed effects modeling to investigate the effect of condition (real, social, non-social) on trust and cooperation. Based on our pilot data, we expect that adolescents cooperate more in the social conditions (H1.2). Exploratory analyses will investigate how information sampling and cooperation are related and whether these measures are related to age and social skills using correlations and controlling for multiple comparisons.
We will also use a computational modeling approach and compare different models of increasing complexity in their ability to predict participants' information sampling choices and cooperation strategies on the trust game. The information sampling task and model-space has been introduced in a previous study(Ma et al., 2018). In brief, the main model space consists of 1) a normative model that considers the participant's cost of sampling, 2) an uncertainty tolerance model that estimates participants uncertainty tolerance and prescribes sampling until tolerance criterion is reached and 3) a threshold model with decision bounds. In line with the previous study, we expect that the uncertainty tolerance model best describes adolescents' information sampling tendencies (H1.1). 
For the in-person iterated trust game, we will investigate which mathematically defined strategies best explain children's decisions to cooperate vs. defect. We will probe fixed strategies (e.g., tit for tat (Rilling et al., 2002; Fehr and Fischbacher, 2004), reinforcement learning (RL, Rosenblau et al., 2018) and combination strategies that rely on fixed strategies or RL and children's tendencies to trust peers (i.e., their tendencies to sample information about peers)). The models will all include a forgiveness parameter. This free parameter will be an estimate of how fast the investor reinitiates cooperation after the trustee defected in each game. Forgiveness is an important ingredient of sustained cooperation (King-Casas et al., 2008) and we expect this forgiveness parameter to be larger in the social compared to non-social condition.
For the individuals' fNIRS data analysis, we will test whether changes in oxygenated hemoglobin (oxy-Hb) across all channels are larger in the social vs. non-social conditions (H.2.1), whether they scale with the predictions of the winning behavioral model on a trial by trial basis (H.2.2). For the analysis of synchronization between partners in the real interaction, we will perform wavelet transform coherence analyses (WTC; Faugeras et al., 2004). This method measures cross-correlation between two time series as a function of frequency and time. As such it can detect significant coherence between two time series of participant pairs to address our hypothesis (H.3.1) that synchronization levels of partners will predict cooperation levels and forgiveness rates in the real interaction condition.

q21.value:
We will investigate differences between the real, social and non-social conditions of the trust game using linear mixed model analyses. We will test for main effects of condition with the p < 0.05 significance criterion. The same criterion will be applied to the correlation analyses (e.g., percent shared in the social condition and social skills). Here we will use a Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons.
For the computational modeling analysis, model evidence will be assessed with the Bayesian information criterion (BIC) for each individual (BIC = n * ln(RSS/n) + k * ln(n)). RSS is the residual sum of squared errors, n is the number of trials, k is the number of free parameters in the model, and "ln" is the natural logarithm. The BIC penalizes for model complexity (i.e., the number of parameters in the model). BIC scores are summed over participants and differences between the summed BIC scores indicate, which model is best.
We also calculate confusion matrices, check recovery of parameter estimates, and test which models would be optimal for the two tasks.

q22.value: Datasets are excluded when participants did not provide answer on the information sampling task and trust game (i.e., 25% of missing data) and if participants made the same decision to not sample information or keep all coins more than 90% of the time. For fNIRS data, we will exclude participants with more than 25% channels with low light levels. Decisions to exclude trials due to fNIRS artifacts will be based on established multi-method preprocessing pipelines for fNIRS data (Brigadoi et al., 2014).

q23.value: Datasets are excluded if > 25% of the data points are missing (which can happen if participants do not answer in the allotted time).

q24.value: We expect that sampling information about the trustworthiness of another is related to cooperation and that they are also related to age and social skills. We will therefore investigate these relationships between the amount of information sampled depending on reciprocation, cooperation rates on the trust game, model parameters, age and social skills.

Trust, a necessary ingredient for both initiating and sustaining cooperation, builds on individual's readiness to explore joint rewards at the risk of facing exploitation by the other party (Adolphs, 2003; Fehr and Fischbacher, 2003). Cooperation is hard to study in systematic, controlled settings due to the fragile nature of trust and its dependence on social context. An example of how it can be studied in a controlled setting is using economic games such as the trust game (Fehr et al., 1993). The trust game is a monetary exchange game in which an investor can send a sum of money to a trustee. The trustee receives a multiple of this sum and can return any amount back to the investor (Berg et al., 1995). Using this game, researchers have demonstrated that humans have an inherent preference to trust and cooperate with people (i.e. in social settings) (Mayer et al., 2014). Studies have found that people are more willing to choose risky options and engage in cooperation with people who have lower reciprocation rates than with non-human slot machines (Fetchenhauer and Dunning, 2012). It remains unclear, however, how the opportunity to gather information about the agent shapes cooperation and how trust is achieved and sustained in social vs. non-social situations. It is also unclear how cooperation changes in adolescence, a time of substantial neural and social development.
Computational models paired with neuroscientific assessment can reveal the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying cooperation in adolescence. We will combine a developmental and neurocomputational approach to test 1) how early adolescents (8-12y, N=50) sample information about their cooperation partners, 2) which strategies they employ when cooperating with social and non-social agents, and 3) whether synchronization of neural activity between agents in the medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC) measured with near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) predicts reciprocal, sustained cooperation.
registration_responses.q4:
We will use the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) to identify optimal information sampling and cooperation strategies of adolescents in social and non-social settings. We will test whether model predictions scale with brain activity and how interpersonal neural synchronization predicts cooperation strategies. The work will proceed as follows:
AIM 1: To identify how adolescents decide to trust a peer and determine cooperation strategies of adolescents in social and non-social settings. We will determine how adolescents sample information about the other peer and how they cooperate with a peer in a repeated economic exchange game (i.e., the trust game). Based on our pilot data (see section 14 below), we expect model-free and model-based differences between social and non-social conditions (social condition: 1. when children play with their peer and 2. when they think they play with their peer but play with a computer algorithm; non-social condition: when children know that they play with the computer algorithm). A forgiveness rate will be estimated as part of model fitting. This variable will determine how fast children choose to share and "forgive" their partner after the partner defected (see section 18). H1.1. In line with a previous study (Ma et al., 2018), we expect that an uncertainty tolerance model that estimates the uncertainty tolerance criterion for each child (see section 18) best describes how children sample information about peers. H1.2. Children will show higher cooperation rates in the social compared to the non-social condition. H1.3. Children will show higher forgiveness rates, estimated by the winning mathematical model, in the social compared to the non-social conditions. 
AIM 2: To identify the neural mechanisms of cooperation. Using fNIRS, we will measure participants' brain activity during the experiment. We will focus on the MPFC, a brain region that has been uniquely involved in social decision making and learning (Behrens et al., 2008; Nicolle et al., 2012). H.2.1. Activity in the MPFC will scale with children's sharing tendencies in the social compared to non-social settings. H.2.2 Predictions of the winning mathematical models scale with neural activity in the MPFC social versus non-social conditions. 
AIM 3: To identify the interpersonal neural synchronization of the MPFC during real interactions. We will investigate the synchronization between investor and trustee pairs by computing the wavelet transform coherence (WTC; Faugeras et al., 2004) for each pair of the participants over time. H.3.1 Synchronization levels of partners will predict cooperation levels and forgiveness rates during the real interaction.

The order of the remaining games in the social and non-social conditions are counterbalanced across pairs of participants.

registration_responses.q11: We have collected behavioral data on the trust game conditions only from a pilot sample of 25 typically developing children (age = 12±2.9y). This was done to optimize parameters for the adaptive computer partners in the trust game. Aside from this behavioral pilot data (trust game task only), no data, has been collected, created, or realized as of the date of submission of this research plan for preregistration. The data collected thus far on a small sample of older participants served as pilot data to optimize experimental procedures.
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 50 participants.
registration_responses.q14: The sample size is based on the number of participants included in previous similar studies, (e.g. (King-Casas et al., 2005; Tang et al., 2015) and on our pilot data. Note that model free and model-based analyses of our pilot data (N=25), revealed differences in reciprocity between social and non-social conditions. In accordance to our hypotheses, children shared more when they thought they were playing with a child (i.e., social condition) compared to when they knew they were interacting with a computer (i.e., non-social condition). Model-based analyses, revealed that a simple tit-for-tat strategy best described participants' sharing tendencies in both social and non-social conditions but the forgiveness rate significantly differed between conditions: investors reinitiated cooperation quicker after the trustee defected in the social condition. These results form the basis for our hypotheses under aims 1 and 2, stated above. To achieve a sample size of 25 participants in the real interaction condition, that is of particular interest for the fNIRS analysis, we have to collect data from 25 participant pairs (i.e., 50 participants).
registration_responses.q21:
We will investigate differences between the real, social and non-social conditions of the trust game using linear mixed model analyses. We will test for main effects of condition with the p < 0.05 significance criterion. The same criterion will be applied to the correlation analyses (e.g., percent shared in the social condition and social skills). Here we will use a Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons.
For the computational modeling analysis, model evidence will be assessed with the Bayesian information criterion (BIC) for each individual (BIC = n * ln(RSS/n) + k * ln(n)). RSS is the residual sum of squared errors, n is the number of trials, k is the number of free parameters in the model, and "ln" is the natural logarithm. The BIC penalizes for model complexity (i.e., the number of parameters in the model). BIC scores are summed over participants and differences between the summed BIC scores indicate, which model is best.
We also calculate confusion matrices, check recovery of parameter estimates, and test which models would be optimal for the two tasks.
registration_responses.q22: Datasets are excluded when participants did not provide answer on the information sampling task and trust game (i.e., 25% of missing data) and if participants made the same decision to not sample information or keep all coins more than 90% of the time. For fNIRS data, we will exclude participants with more than 25% channels with low light levels. Decisions to exclude trials due to fNIRS artifacts will be based on established multi-method preprocessing pipelines for fNIRS data (Brigadoi et al., 2014).
registration_responses.q23: Datasets are excluded if > 25% of the data points are missing (which can happen if participants do not answer in the allotted time).
registration_responses.q24: We expect that sampling information about the trustworthiness of another is related to cooperation and that they are also related to age and social skills. We will therefore investigate these relationships between the amount of information sampled depending on reciprocation, cooperation rates on the trust game, model parameters, age and social skills.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The study consists of an online experiment to test information sampling, and an in-person experiment, in which children will play the trust game in pairs. We will record brain activity during the trust game task using fNIRS.
Participants (N=50, aged 8 to 12y) will first participate in an online study, in which adolescents can sample how trustworthy 60 peers were on similar games. Unbeknown to them, the outcomes of the games are computer generated and designed to have six different reciprocation rates (probability (p) of reciprocation: 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0). Adolescents are then invited into the lab in pairs and will be asked to play a child-friendly version of the trust game with each other and with computer algorithms. Pairs will be matched for age, sex, socioeconomic status and IQ. In each game, participants play multiple trials of the trust game. In this game the investor receives five coins, and can keep the five coins or share any amount with the trustee. If investors choose to share, the trustee will receive four times as many coins and can decide to share half back with the investor or keep all coins. 
	Participants play multiple consecutive games: First, participants play the trust game with each other (i.e. real interaction). One participant is randomly assigned to the trustee condition and the other to the investor condition. Thereafter, they play in the investor role with a computer partner. Before two of the four games, they are told that they are playing with a human (i.e., social condition). In the remaining games participants know that they are playing with computer partners (i.e. non-social condition). The social and non-social conditions are counterbalanced across participants.
While playing the trust game, we will measure participants' brain activity during the tasks using fNIRS. FNIRS is child friendly and tolerant of motion artifacts. It also offers considerable benefits over fMRI since it allows research on online dyadic interaction.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants are recruited through advertisement by flyers around GW and online advertisement (e.g., Facebook and Instagram advertisement). Participants will complete an online study at home (approximately one hour) and an in-person study. The in-person study will take approximately two hours to complete. We expect to test all participants within a year of the start of data collection. The experiment will be completely conducted at George Washington University and we will only include participants between 8-12 years old. After completing the online study, participants will be matched for age, sex and socioeconomic variables and invited to the in-person visit in pairs. During this visit, children sit next to each other in front of a computer. Desks are separated by dividers. Each child will wear an fNIRS cap, to collect brain activity simultaneously during all experimental conditions.
registration_responses.q16.question: Every participant gets the exact same tasks (in different order).
registration_responses.q17.question: We will record participants' choices on the online information sampling task and in the trust game conditions. In the trust game conditions, we will also simultaneously record changes in oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin concentrations via fNIRS.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use linear mixed effects modeling to investigate the effect of condition (real, social, non-social) on trust and cooperation. Based on our pilot data, we expect that adolescents cooperate more in the social conditions (H1.2). Exploratory analyses will investigate how information sampling and cooperation are related and whether these measures are related to age and social skills using correlations and controlling for multiple comparisons.
We will also use a computational modeling approach and compare different models of increasing complexity in their ability to predict participants' information sampling choices and cooperation strategies on the trust game. The information sampling task and model-space has been introduced in a previous study(Ma et al., 2018). In brief, the main model space consists of 1) a normative model that considers the participant's cost of sampling, 2) an uncertainty tolerance model that estimates participants uncertainty tolerance and prescribes sampling until tolerance criterion is reached and 3) a threshold model with decision bounds. In line with the previous study, we expect that the uncertainty tolerance model best describes adolescents' information sampling tendencies (H1.1). 
For the in-person iterated trust game, we will investigate which mathematically defined strategies best explain children's decisions to cooperate vs. defect. We will probe fixed strategies (e.g., tit for tat (Rilling et al., 2002; Fehr and Fischbacher, 2004), reinforcement learning (RL, Rosenblau et al., 2018) and combination strategies that rely on fixed strategies or RL and children's tendencies to trust peers (i.e., their tendencies to sample information about peers)). The models will all include a forgiveness parameter. This free parameter will be an estimate of how fast the investor reinitiates cooperation after the trustee defected in each game. Forgiveness is an important ingredient of sustained cooperation (King-Casas et al., 2008) and we expect this forgiveness parameter to be larger in the social compared to non-social condition.
For the individuals' fNIRS data analysis, we will test whether changes in oxygenated hemoglobin (oxy-Hb) across all channels are larger in the social vs. non-social conditions (H.2.1), whether they scale with the predictions of the winning behavioral model on a trial by trial basis (H.2.2). For the analysis of synchronization between partners in the real interaction, we will perform wavelet transform coherence analyses (WTC; Faugeras et al., 2004). This method measures cross-correlation between two time series as a function of frequency and time. As such it can detect significant coherence between two time series of participant pairs to address our hypothesis (H.3.1) that synchronization levels of partners will predict cooperation levels and forgiveness rates in the real interaction condition.

q1.value: Deference to Experts with Normative vs. Counternormative Values

q3.value: The broader project of which this study is a part concerns whether people defer selectively to experts who share their moral values. The other studies in this project have looked at individual differences (i.e., experts who share vs. differ on political ideology), whereas this study is looking at experts who endorse vs. reject socially common values.

q4.value:
H1: An expert who endorses socially common values will be more persuasive than an expert who rejects socially common values. Specifically, there will be a larger difference in product ratings between endorsed vs. unendorsed products for an expert endorsing rather than rejecting social values.

H2: This effect will be (at least partially) mediated by perceived competence. That is, experts who reject dominant values will be perceived as lower in competence, which in turn makes those experts less persuasive.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions in a computerized task. Participants do not know what the experimental manipulation is, since they are in only one of two between-subjects conditions.

question.value: Mixed design with 2 factors. The between-subjects factor has two levels (expert endorses or rejects socially common values) and the within-subjects factor has two levels (expert recommends vs. dis-recommends the product) with 4 repeated measures within each condition (i.e., a total of 8 items divided among 2 conditions).

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two conditions. The eight items are divided into two counterbalancing groups (A and B) of 4 items each; for half of participants, the expert recommends A and dis-recommends B, whereas for the other half of participants, the experts recommends B and dis-recommends A. The order of the eight items is randomized. Finally, the order of the judgments about the expert (competence, truthfulness, and similarity) is randomized for each participant. All randomization is simple randomization as performed by Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited and compensated through Amazon Mechanical Turk, restricting the sample to U.S. participants. We will only recruit workers who have completed at least 500 HITs and have at least 95% HIT approval rating. A list of workers who have completed other studies within the broader project will not be eligible for participation.

q14.value: A sample size of N=400 is sufficient to achieve 90% power for small to medium effects (d>0.33) in a between-subjects design.

question.value:
The between-subjects manipulation is advisor values (supports vs. rejects socially common values). This is manipulated by giving three examples of titles of newspaper columns written by each expert (e.g., "Why community matters" vs. "The virtue of unfairness").

The within-subjects manipulation is whether the advisor recommends vs. dis-recommends a product. This is achieved by reporting the expert's star rating (1 or 4) and an excerpt of a written review (positive or negative).

Product ratings: For each of 8 products, participants will be asked to express their purchase intentions (e.g., "What is the probability that you would consider purchasing this dehumidifier?") on a scale from 0% to 100%.

Advisor ratings: After the main task, each participant will rate their agreement with the truthfulness ("I trust Tim to give his objective opinion about the products"), competence ("I believe that Tim has good judgment about products"), and moral similarity ("Tim and I share the same moral value system") of the expert. These ratings are all made on 0 ("Strongly disagree") to 10 ("Strongly agree") scales.
We will average across the 4 items in each condition (expert recommends vs. dis-recommends).

Manipulation check: We will use a t-test to compare ratings of value similarity between the two conditions.

H1: We will compute a difference score for each participant by subtracting the (averaged) ratings for products recommended vs. dis-recommended by the expert. A t-test will be used to test whether these difference scores are larger among participants in the condition with the expert who supports (vs. rejects) socially common values.

H2: We will use parallel mediation analysis (PROCESS Model 4). The IV will be condition (expert supports vs. rejects society's dominant values), the DV will be the difference scores above, and the mediators will be competence and trustworthiness ratings.

q21.value: We will use NHST with alpha = .05 and two-tailed tests. Bootstrapping will be used for testing mediation hypotheses, with a 95% confidence interval.

q22.value:
Participants will be excluded if they fail one of two attention/comprehension checks: (1) a set of 5 multiple-choice questions testing comprehension of the expert's biography, and (2) a set of 12 true/false questions testing memory for the products displayed during the task. Participants will be excluded if they incorrectly answer more than 30% of either set of questions (i.e., more than 1 question from set (1) or more than 3 questions from set (2)).

Since the manipulation check is on the between-subjects manipulation, it cannot easily be used to identify individual participants for whom the manipulation failed. Thus, we will analyze the data two ways with respect to the manipulation check. In one analysis, we will not exclude any participants based on their answer to the moral similarity question. In a second analysis, we will exclude the 20% of participants in each condition who responded most weakly to the manipulation (i.e., when the advisor endorses common social values, the 20% who rate the advisor lowest on moral similarity; when the advisor rejects common social values, the 20% who rate the advisor highest on moral similarity).

q23.value: Any participant with missing data on a key measure (i.e., a product rating or expert rating) will be excluded from data analysis.

q25.value: In this study, perceived truthfulness as well as perceived competence might potentially mediate the effect of expert values on persuasiveness. We have no specific hypothesis about this.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will recruit 300 participants. We will use a random number generator to randomly assign participants to one of the two conditions. Thus, we expect to recruit approximately 150 participants in the dairy condition and 150 participants in the vegan condition.

analyses.value:
First, we will conduct three separate independent samples t-tests to test for differences in each outcome (taste liking, amount of ice cream eaten, and purchase intention) between the two conditions. We will conduct a Welch-adjusted t-test if a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups.

Second, we will conduct three separate multiple-mediation models (one for each outcome) using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R in order to test whether the effect of ice cream type (i.e., dairy versus vegan) on each outcome is mediated by perceived naturalness and/or normalness of the ice cream.

Third, we will conduct separate ordinary least squares regressions to test whether the effect of ice cream type on each outcome is moderated by gender, concern for purity, endorsement of carnism, vegan stigma consciousness, and/or political orientation. For each outcome, we will conduct five separate regressions to test whether this effect varies across levels of each of these five variables. For gender, we will regress the outcome on gender, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for gender and condition. For purity, we will regress the outcome on purity, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for purity and condition. For carnism, we will regress the outcome on carnism, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for carnism and condition. For vegan stigma consciousness, we will regress the outcome on vegan stigma consciousness, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for vegan stigma consciousness and condition. For political orientation, we will regress the outcome on political orientation, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for political orientation and condition.

Fourth, among men, we will test whether the effect of ice cream type on each outcome is moderated by endorsement of self-ascribed masculinity, separately regressing each outcome on self-ascribed masculinity, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for self-ascribed masculinity and condition.

Fifth, among men, we will test whether the effect of ice cream type on each outcome is moderated by endorsement of precarious manhood, separately regressing each outcome on precarious manhood, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for precarious manhood and condition.

An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from taking part in this study if they have any dietary restrictions, preferences, or allergies that make them unable to consume, or uncomfortable consuming, any of the following food items: dairy, nuts, eggs, soy, peanuts, tree nuts, and/or coconut. Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are vegetarian/vegan, fail an attention check in the survey, fail to taste the ice cream (i.e., if they consume less than 1 gram of the ice cream), or enter that they are either an unpermitted (<18 years) or an impossible (>117 years) age. Participants who indicate that they are neither a man nor woman will be excluded from analyses that involve gender as a variable.

dependent.value:
The dependent variables for this study are taste liking of the ice cream, amount of the ice cream consumed, and intention to purchase the ice cream.

Taste liking in the dairy ice cream condition will be assessed by the following four items: “The taste of this ice cream is...” “The flavor of this ice cream is...” “The texture of this ice cream is...” and “The consistency of this ice cream is...” with responses ranging from 1 (very bad) to 7 (very delicious). For participants in the vegan ice cream condition, the word “vegan” in each item will be added before “ice cream.”

Amount of the ice cream consumed will be operationalized as the difference between the initial weight of the bowl of ice cream when it is served to a participant and the final weight of the bowl after that participant has completed the study.

Intention to purchase the ice cream in the dairy ice cream condition will be assessed by the question, “If you were in the mood for ice cream, how likely would you be to purchase this ice cream ($3 per pint) at a store?” with responses ranging from 1 (very unlikely) to 7 (very likely). For participants in the vegan ice cream condition, the word “vegan” will be added before “ice cream.”

Mediator variables for this study are perceived naturalness of the ice cream and perceived normalness of the ice cream.

Perceived naturalness of the ice cream for participants in the dairy ice cream condition will be assessed by the following three items: “This ice cream seems natural,” “This ice cream seems artificial” (reverse-scored), and “This ice cream seems unnatural” (reverse-scored), with responses ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). For participants in the vegan ice cream condition, the word “vegan” will be added in each of these three items before “ice cream.”

Perceived normalness of the ice cream for participants in the dairy ice cream condition will be assessed by the following three items: “This ice cream seems normal,” “This ice cream seems weird” (reverse-scored), and “This ice cream seems abnormal” (reverse-scored), with responses ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). For participants in the vegan ice cream condition, the word “vegan” will be added in each of these three items before “ice cream.”

Moderator variables are gender, self-ascribed masculinity, endorsement of precarious manhood, concern for purity, endorsement of carnism, vegan stigma consciousness, and political orientation.

Gender will be assessed by the item, “Please select your gender,” with responses including “Man,” “Woman,” “Non-Binary,” and “Other.”

Self-ascribed masculinity will be assessed by Kachel et al.’s (2016) traditional masculinity/femininity scale, which is comprised of the following six items: “I consider myself as…” “Ideally, I would like to be…” “Traditionally, my interests would be considered as…” “Traditionally, my attitudes and beliefs would be considered as…” “Traditionally, my behavior would be considered as…” and “Traditionally, my outer appearance would be considered as…” Responses will range from 1 (very feminine) to 7 (very masculine).

Endorsement of precarious manhood will be assessed by the following seven items: “It’s fairly easy for a man to lose his status as a man,” “A male’s status as a real man sometimes depends on how other people view him,” “A man needs to prove his masculinity,” “A boy needs to become a man; it doesn’t ‘just happen',” “The title of ‘manhood’ needs to be reserved for those who deserve it,” “You’re not a man if you don’t like masculine things,” and “A real man enjoys a bit of danger now and then,” with responses ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Concern for purity will be assessed by the 3-item purity subscale of the Moral Foundations Questionnaire, which measures the extent to which considerations of purity are relevant to participants’ moral judgments. An example item is “whether or not someone did something disgusting.” Responses will range from 1 (not at all relevant) to 6 (extremely relevant).

Endorsement of carnism will be assessed by the 8-item Carnism Inventory. An example item is “Humans should continue to eat meat because we've been doing it for thousands of years.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Vegan stigma consciousness will be assessed by the following six items: “There are bad stereotypes about being a vegan,” “People tend to be judged negatively for going vegan,” “There is stigma surrounding being a vegan,” “People tend to view vegans in an unfavorable light,” “Most people think that vegans are weird,” and “Most people think that vegans are annoying,” with responses ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Political orientation will be assessed by the following question: “On the following scale from 1 (very liberal) to 7 (very conservative), how would you rate your political views?”

conditions.value: There are two conditions in this survey: a dairy ice cream condition and a vegan ice cream condition. Participants will be assigned to one of these conditions at random. This manipulation will be implemented in the following manner. When it is time in the study for a participant to taste the ice cream, the researcher will serve them a bowl with four scoops of Breyers Natural Vanilla ice cream and will read to them the following script: “We’re interested in hearing what you think of this ice cream. Feel free to eat as much or as little of it as you’d like. Once you’ve tasted enough of the ice cream to get a sufficient tasting, please complete the rest of the survey on the computer. You are welcome to continue to eat the ice cream as you complete the survey. When you are finished with the survey, please ring the doorbell to let me know.” For participants in the dairy condition, the researcher will read this exact script. For participants in the vegan condition, the researcher will read this same script but with the word “vegan” before each instance of “ice cream.”

hypothesis.value: The purpose of this study is to investigate attitudes toward vegan ice cream. All participants in this study will eat dairy ice cream but half will be told that they are eating vegan ice cream. Through a between-subjects experimental design with two conditions (dairy ice cream label, vegan ice cream label), we will examine whether telling people that they are eating vegan ice cream (when in reality they are eating dairy ice cream) makes them (1) rate the ice cream as tasting worse, (2) eat less of the ice cream, and (3) be less likely to want to purchase the ice cream at a store, along with mediators and moderators of each of these three effects. We hypothesize that, compared to dairy ice cream (control condition) participants, participants who are told they are eating vegan ice cream will (1) rate the ice cream as tasting worse, (2) eat less of the ice cream, and (3) be less likely to want to purchase the ice cream at a store. We hypothesize that the effect of ice cream condition on each of these three outcomes will be mediated by perceived naturalness and normalness of the ice cream (i.e., lower perceived naturalness and normalness of vegan ice cream relative to dairy ice cream). We hypothesize that the effect of ice cream condition on each of the three outcomes will be moderated by gender (larger for men compared to women), reliance on the moral foundation of purity (larger for higher purity), endorsement of carnism (larger for higher carnism), vegan stigma consciousness (larger for higher consciousness), and political orientation (larger for more conservative, compared to liberal, orientation). We hypothesize that, among men, this effect will be moderated by self-ascribed masculinity (larger for higher masculinity) and endorsement of precarious manhood (larger for higher precarious manhood).

registration_responses.name: Ice Cream Study 2
registration_responses.sample: We will recruit 300 participants. We will use a random number generator to randomly assign participants to one of the two conditions. Thus, we expect to recruit approximately 150 participants in the dairy condition and 150 participants in the vegan condition.
registration_responses.analyses:
First, we will conduct three separate independent samples t-tests to test for differences in each outcome (taste liking, amount of ice cream eaten, and purchase intention) between the two conditions. We will conduct a Welch-adjusted t-test if a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups.

Second, we will conduct three separate multiple-mediation models (one for each outcome) using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R in order to test whether the effect of ice cream type (i.e., dairy versus vegan) on each outcome is mediated by perceived naturalness and/or normalness of the ice cream.

Third, we will conduct separate ordinary least squares regressions to test whether the effect of ice cream type on each outcome is moderated by gender, concern for purity, endorsement of carnism, vegan stigma consciousness, and/or political orientation. For each outcome, we will conduct five separate regressions to test whether this effect varies across levels of each of these five variables. For gender, we will regress the outcome on gender, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for gender and condition. For purity, we will regress the outcome on purity, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for purity and condition. For carnism, we will regress the outcome on carnism, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for carnism and condition. For vegan stigma consciousness, we will regress the outcome on vegan stigma consciousness, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for vegan stigma consciousness and condition. For political orientation, we will regress the outcome on political orientation, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for political orientation and condition.

Fourth, among men, we will test whether the effect of ice cream type on each outcome is moderated by endorsement of self-ascribed masculinity, separately regressing each outcome on self-ascribed masculinity, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for self-ascribed masculinity and condition.

Fifth, among men, we will test whether the effect of ice cream type on each outcome is moderated by endorsement of precarious manhood, separately regressing each outcome on precarious manhood, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for precarious manhood and condition.

An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.
registration_responses.outliers: Participants will be excluded from taking part in this study if they have any dietary restrictions, preferences, or allergies that make them unable to consume, or uncomfortable consuming, any of the following food items: dairy, nuts, eggs, soy, peanuts, tree nuts, and/or coconut. Participants will be excluded from analyses if they indicate that they are vegetarian/vegan, fail an attention check in the survey, fail to taste the ice cream (i.e., if they consume less than 1 gram of the ice cream), or enter that they are either an unpermitted (<18 years) or an impossible (>117 years) age. Participants who indicate that they are neither a man nor woman will be excluded from analyses that involve gender as a variable.
