data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will recruit 300 participants. We will set Qualtrics to randomly present participants with one of the two conditions. Thus, we expect to recruit approximately 150 participants in the low-calorie condition and 150 participants in the high-calorie condition.

analyses.value: First, we will conduct an independent samples t-test to test whether participants’ beliefs about the healthfulness of high-calorie ice cream differ from their beliefs about the healthfulness of low-calorie ice cream. We will conduct a Welch-adjusted t-test if a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups. Second, we will conduct a multiple-mediation model using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R in order to test whether the effect of calorie count on perceived healthfulness is mediated by weight concern and/or disease concern. An effect is considered to be significant if it yields a p-value of less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from taking part in this study if they have any dietary restrictions, preferences, or allergies that make them unable to consume, or uncomfortable consuming, any of the following food items: dairy, nuts, eggs, soy, peanuts, tree nuts, and/or coconut. Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail an attention check in the survey, fail to taste the ice cream (i.e., if they consume less than 1 gram of the ice cream), or enter that they are either an unpermitted (<18 years) or an impossible (>117 years) age.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable for this study is perceived healthfulness of the ice cream, which will be assessed by the question: “How healthy is this type of ice cream?” with responses ranging from 1 (very unhealthy) to 7 (very healthy).

Mediator variables for this study are weight and disease concerns related to eating the ice cream.

Weight concern will be assessed by the following two items: “Eating this ice cream will make me gain weight” and “This ice cream is fattening,” with responses ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Disease concern will be assessed by the following three items: “Eating this ice cream will raise my cholesterol,” “Eating this ice cream will increase my risk for heart disease,” and “Eating this ice cream will increase my risk for diabetes,” with responses ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

The independent variable for this study is calorie count. All participants will be served a bowl with four scoops of Breyers Natural Vanilla ice cream and will be asked to taste the ice cream. After responding to items assessing what they think of the ice cream (e.g., how it tastes), participants will be presented with information on the calorie count of the ice cream they have tasted. In the low-calorie condition, this statement will read, “The serving of ice cream you received had 125 calories.” In the high-calorie condition, this statement will read, “The serving of ice cream you received had 500 calories.”

conditions.value: There are two conditions in this survey: a low-calorie ice cream condition and a high-calorie ice cream condition.

hypothesis.value: The purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of calorie count on perceptions of healthfulness of ice cream. Through a between-subjects experimental design with two conditions (low calorie, high calorie), we will examine whether people report that high-calorie ice cream is less healthful than is low-calorie ice cream, along with mediators of this effect. We hypothesize that participants will report that high-calorie ice cream is less healthful than low-calorie ice cream. We hypothesize that this effect will be mediated by weight and disease concerns related to eating the ice cream (i.e., higher weight and disease concerns related to high-calorie ice cream relative to low-calorie ice cream).

attributes.title: Public attitudes on community gun violence

q1.value: Public attitudes on community gun violence

q4.value:
1. The structural news article will lower stereotypical attributions of gun violence.
2. The structural news will alter support for criminal justice policies (decreased support for punitive policies and increased support for restorative policies).
3. Stereotypical attributions of gun violence in poor, inner-city communities of color will be positively associated with support for punitive criminal justice policies.
4. Stereotypical attributions of gun violence in poor, inner-city communities of color will be negatively associated with support for restorative criminal justice policies.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: A three-group randomized, between-subject experiment.

q9.value: Qualtrics will randomize participants in real time during the online experiment session.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants recruited on Amazon Mechanical Turk will be asked to take an online survey on the Qualtrics website for monetary compensation. After consenting to participate in a study about information evaluation, they will be randomly assigned into one of three conditions: 1) structural, 2) naive structural, and 3) control. The structural and naive structural article will present information about gun violence and the control article will present information unrelated to gun violence. Participants will be asked to read the news article associated with their assigned condition, answer comprehension checks about their respective news article, and then answer questions about their personal attitudes and demographics.

q13.value: We expect to have 400 participants per condition for a total sample size of 1,200 participants.

q14.value: The sample size was determined by balancing cost against the anticipated need for statistical power. We plan to recruit 500 participants per condition (total: 1,500) with the goal of retaining 400 usable participants per condition (total 1,200). We anticipate that roughly 20% of participants will fail attention checks or be a statistical outlier in terms of the time spent to complete the study. Because these exclusions must occur after random assignment, all analyses will also be reported including all randomly-participants.

question.value:
Participants will be randomized to one of three conditions: 
• Structural: read an article that explains the causal effect of structural inequality and poverty on gun violence; and recommends policies that support structural development to prevent gun violence.
• Naïve Structural: read an article that mentions (without providing a detailed explanation of) that structural inequality and poverty are important causes of gun violence and recommends policies that support structural development to prevent gun violence.
• Control: read a paragraph that describes the extent of gun violence in poor, inner-city communities of color (presented after reading and answering questions about an unrelated article on e-cigarette use).

- KEY DEPENDENT VARIABLES -

Stereotypical attributions about community gun violence: 
Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they agree with four items on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). The first item is included only to reduce social desirability concerns and will not be included in analyses. We expect that participants will feel licensed to express stereotypical beliefs if they are first given a chance to express that there are “decent, hard-working people” living in poor, inner-city neighborhoods. 
1. “If we could get violent criminals off the streets of poor inner-city neighborhoods, the decent, hard-working people in those neighborhoods could lift themselves out of poverty.”
2. "Gun violence in poor inner-city neighborhoods won’t improve unless we get the criminals who are doing the shooting off the streets for good."
3.  “We wouldn’t have so much gun violence in poor inner-city neighborhoods if the kids doing the shooting had parents who took responsibility for raising them.”
4. “If the people doing the shooting in poor inner-city neighborhoods knew they would be caught and severely punished, we’d see a lot less gun violence in those neighborhoods.”

Support for punitive public policies: 
Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they oppose or favor four items on a scale from 1 (strongly oppose) to 7 (strongly favor): 
1. More police on the streets
2. Longer jail terms for those convicted of violent crimes
3. More prisons and fewer opportunities for parole
4. Increase criminal penalties for non-violent crimes (i.e., property crimes and theft)

Support for restorative public policies: 
Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they oppose or favor four items on a scale from 1 (strongly oppose) to 7 (strongly favor):
	1. More job and community programs for young people
	2. Job programs for people in the inner-cities
	3. More federal assistance to the poor
	4. Remove criminal-history questions from employment applications

- COVARIATES -

Demographics:
1. Racial identification
2. Gender identification
3. Political party
4. Political orientation
5. Age
6. Annual income
7. Number of people living in household
8. Highest level of education

- EXPLORATORY MEASURES -

Support for gun control: 
Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they oppose or favor stricter gun control policies from 1 (strongly oppose) to 7 (strongly favor).

Open-ended attribution for gun violence disparity: 
Participants will be asked to answer the following prompt to explore spontaneous attributions for racial disparities in gun violence: 
1. According to CDC, Black men are much more likely than white men to be involved in gun-related homicides. Why do you think that is?

Perception of criminality: 
The following questions are single-item exploratory measures related to participants perception of criminals in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color with high rates of gun violence. Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they agree with the following items on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree):
1. “No matter what the circumstances are, people who become involved in gun violence are solely responsible for their choices to commit crime.”
2. “Conditions in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color make it practically impossible for some kids to avoid getting involved with crime.”
3. “Some people in poor, inner-city neighborhoods are just born criminals and there’s not much other people can do to change that.”
4. “Some people in poor, inner-city neighborhoods who commit crimes were just not raised right and there’s not much that can be done to change that.”
5. “Even if someone becomes involved with crime in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color, it’s possible for them to change if given the right kind of support.”
6. “It’s very hard for some people living in poor inner-city neighborhoods of color to avoid committing crimes in order to make a living.”

Perception of unemployment in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color: 
The following questions are single-item exploratory measures related to participants perception of unemployment in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color with high rates of gun violence. Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they agree with the following items on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree):
1. “Certain groups have high unemployment rates because they don’t have a strong work ethic. “
2. “Certain groups have higher unemployment rates than others because of societal factors beyond their control”
3. “Certain groups have high unemployment rates because they do not have equal opportunities.
4. “Certain groups have high unemployment rates because they do not want to work.”

Perceived likelihood of personal involvement in gun violence: 
Participants will be asked to respond to the following prompt on a scale of 1=absolutely impossible, 2=extremely unlikely, 3=very unlikely, 4=somewhat unlikely, 5=slightly unlikely, 6=neither likely nor unlikely, 7=slightly likely, 8=somewhat likely, 9=very likely, 10=extremely likely, 11=absolutely possible. They will then be asked to provide an open-ended explanation of their answer in a couple of sentences.
1. Imagine that you had grown up in a poor, inner-city neighborhood with high rates of gun violence and little opportunity for legal employment. How likely do you think it is that you would have fallen into a path that led you to become involved in gun violence?

Stereotypical attributions about community gun violence: A composite score will be created for each participant by averaging their responses to all four items. 

Support for punitive public policies: A composite score will be created for each participant by averaging their responses to all four items.

registration_responses.q8.question: A three-group randomized, between-subject experiment.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants recruited on Amazon Mechanical Turk will be asked to take an online survey on the Qualtrics website for monetary compensation. After consenting to participate in a study about information evaluation, they will be randomly assigned into one of three conditions: 1) structural, 2) naive structural, and 3) control. The structural and naive structural article will present information about gun violence and the control article will present information unrelated to gun violence. Participants will be asked to read the news article associated with their assigned condition, answer comprehension checks about their respective news article, and then answer questions about their personal attitudes and demographics.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Participants will be randomized to one of three conditions: 
• Structural: read an article that explains the causal effect of structural inequality and poverty on gun violence; and recommends policies that support structural development to prevent gun violence.
• Naïve Structural: read an article that mentions (without providing a detailed explanation of) that structural inequality and poverty are important causes of gun violence and recommends policies that support structural development to prevent gun violence.
• Control: read a paragraph that describes the extent of gun violence in poor, inner-city communities of color (presented after reading and answering questions about an unrelated article on e-cigarette use).
registration_responses.q17.question:
- KEY DEPENDENT VARIABLES -

Stereotypical attributions about community gun violence: 
Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they agree with four items on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). The first item is included only to reduce social desirability concerns and will not be included in analyses. We expect that participants will feel licensed to express stereotypical beliefs if they are first given a chance to express that there are “decent, hard-working people” living in poor, inner-city neighborhoods. 
1. “If we could get violent criminals off the streets of poor inner-city neighborhoods, the decent, hard-working people in those neighborhoods could lift themselves out of poverty.”
2. "Gun violence in poor inner-city neighborhoods won’t improve unless we get the criminals who are doing the shooting off the streets for good."
3.  “We wouldn’t have so much gun violence in poor inner-city neighborhoods if the kids doing the shooting had parents who took responsibility for raising them.”
4. “If the people doing the shooting in poor inner-city neighborhoods knew they would be caught and severely punished, we’d see a lot less gun violence in those neighborhoods.”

Support for punitive public policies: 
Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they oppose or favor four items on a scale from 1 (strongly oppose) to 7 (strongly favor): 
1. More police on the streets
2. Longer jail terms for those convicted of violent crimes
3. More prisons and fewer opportunities for parole
4. Increase criminal penalties for non-violent crimes (i.e., property crimes and theft)

Support for restorative public policies: 
Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they oppose or favor four items on a scale from 1 (strongly oppose) to 7 (strongly favor):
	1. More job and community programs for young people
	2. Job programs for people in the inner-cities
	3. More federal assistance to the poor
	4. Remove criminal-history questions from employment applications

- COVARIATES -

Demographics:
1. Racial identification
2. Gender identification
3. Political party
4. Political orientation
5. Age
6. Annual income
7. Number of people living in household
8. Highest level of education

- EXPLORATORY MEASURES -

Support for gun control: 
Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they oppose or favor stricter gun control policies from 1 (strongly oppose) to 7 (strongly favor).

Open-ended attribution for gun violence disparity: 
Participants will be asked to answer the following prompt to explore spontaneous attributions for racial disparities in gun violence: 
1. According to CDC, Black men are much more likely than white men to be involved in gun-related homicides. Why do you think that is?

Perception of criminality: 
The following questions are single-item exploratory measures related to participants perception of criminals in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color with high rates of gun violence. Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they agree with the following items on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree):
1. “No matter what the circumstances are, people who become involved in gun violence are solely responsible for their choices to commit crime.”
2. “Conditions in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color make it practically impossible for some kids to avoid getting involved with crime.”
3. “Some people in poor, inner-city neighborhoods are just born criminals and there’s not much other people can do to change that.”
4. “Some people in poor, inner-city neighborhoods who commit crimes were just not raised right and there’s not much that can be done to change that.”
5. “Even if someone becomes involved with crime in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color, it’s possible for them to change if given the right kind of support.”
6. “It’s very hard for some people living in poor inner-city neighborhoods of color to avoid committing crimes in order to make a living.”

Perception of unemployment in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color: 
The following questions are single-item exploratory measures related to participants perception of unemployment in poor, inner-city neighborhoods of color with high rates of gun violence. Participants will be asked to rate the extent to which they agree with the following items on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree):
1. “Certain groups have high unemployment rates because they don’t have a strong work ethic. “
2. “Certain groups have higher unemployment rates than others because of societal factors beyond their control”
3. “Certain groups have high unemployment rates because they do not have equal opportunities.
4. “Certain groups have high unemployment rates because they do not want to work.”

Perceived likelihood of personal involvement in gun violence: 
Participants will be asked to respond to the following prompt on a scale of 1=absolutely impossible, 2=extremely unlikely, 3=very unlikely, 4=somewhat unlikely, 5=slightly unlikely, 6=neither likely nor unlikely, 7=slightly likely, 8=somewhat likely, 9=very likely, 10=extremely likely, 11=absolutely possible. They will then be asked to provide an open-ended explanation of their answer in a couple of sentences.
1. Imagine that you had grown up in a poor, inner-city neighborhood with high rates of gun violence and little opportunity for legal employment. How likely do you think it is that you would have fallen into a path that led you to become involved in gun violence?
